newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Congo's Kabila tested by choice of government team.
newsitem.headline: Congo's Kabila tested by choice of government team.

text.p: After his triumphant takeover of Kinshasa, Laurent Kabila now seems to face problems with the task of forming a government for his Democractic Republic of Congo.
The self-declared president of ex-Zaire missed his latest deadline on Thursday for announcing a team to take charge after toppling former dictator Mobutu Sese Seko's 32-year rule.
A new administration has been expected since Tuesday following Saturday's capture of the capital by Kabila's Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo (AFDL).
There was also no sign of a planned meeting between Kabila and populist opposition leader Etienne Tshisekedi, whose supporters are demanding a role in the new state.

Kabila has been cloistered with key associates in the prime minister's residence since arriving in Kinshasa unnanounced on Tuesday night. A close aide said a new government would be announced on state television at 1930 GMT but the deadline lasped without official explanation.
A studio had been pr%pared at state television for the announcement but there was no sign of Kabila's information commissioner Raphael Gbenda who said he would unveil the team.
State television said an announcement was still expected.
Tshisekedi's fanatical followers have been campaigining for a role for their hero, even threatening street marches if he were not made prime minister in Kabila's government.

Hundreds of militants have been virtually camping in solidarity outside Tshisekedi's home. Their leaders worked the crowd to a frenzy on Thursday with speeches reminding Kabila that their own campaign paved the way for last Saturday's overthrow of Mobutu, who is now in Togo.
"We put Mobutu in a political ambulance and the AFDL took him to the cemetery," declared Tshisekedi's close associate Joseph Olengankoy.
It was not immediately clear whether the delay in coming up with a new government was linked to Tshisekedi's position.
State television meanwhile announced another military triumph for Kabila's alliance forces -- the capture of the country's only seaport of Matadi on the Atlantic near Angola.
The guerrillas who began their long trek across Zaire from the shores of Lake Kivu last October took Matadi "without meeting any resistance", the TV said. It did not say when.
Matadi is also a rail terminal located close to the former Zaire's only refinery and the huge Inga hydro-electric dam. It was the only major city not yet under control of Kabila's guerrillas.
Many former soldiers loyal to Mobutu were reported fleeing towards Matadi. Officials in Angola said on Thursday about 25,000 people, including armed men, had crossed over from Kabila's Congo.

In a sign of growing international acceptance of the new regime, the United Nations said it had been officially told that Kinshasa's envoy now represented Kabila, and would comply with a letter informing it that the country was reviving the name, flag and anthem it had on independence from Belgium in June 1960.
The European Union said it hoped for a broad-based transitional government and would send a mission to convey its views to Kabila.
Western powers have catiously voiced backing for Kabila, linking full recognition and economic aid to progress on broad-based democratic rule.
